1.title: fix comment of `computeSwapStep`
1.body:
`computeSwapStep` doesn't necessarily compute result of a swap within a single tick, instead should be within a tick boundary.

As `sqrtRatioTargetX96` may be the price of the next initialized tick(LP liquidity boundary), which may be well beyond a single tick.

`computeSwapStep` only cares about boundary because liquidity only changes across a boundary, or say, the liquidity doesn't change for intermediate ticks.

1.title: allow compiler >=0.8.0
1.body:
This PR updates the computation of the largest power of two divisor of the denominator in the mulDiv function. It replaces:
```solidity
uint256 twos = -denominator & denominator;
```
with
```solidity
uint256 twos = denominator & (~denominator + 1);
```
The new expression is equivalent to the original but uses an explicit two's complement computation, improving code clarity and readability.

All tests pass, and the change does not alter the functionality of the code.
Also allows the compilation for compilers above 0.8.0

1.title: Feature Request: Uniswap V3 sqrtPrice, require token decimals as input
1.body:
### Feature Request

I propose adding token decimal values as an input parameter to the `sqrtPrice` function in Uniswap V3. This would help improve the accuracy of position and liquidity calculations, particularly for pools involving USDC pairs or any other pairs with differing decimals.

### Rationale

Currently, the Uniswap V3 UI sometimes displays misleading information about positions and liquidity, especially when the token pairs have different decimals. This inaccuracy can result in flawed decision-making processes for traders and liquidity providers.

### Proposed Solution

Extend the `sqrtPrice` function to accept the decimal counts of the paired tokens as an argument. Then, adjust the underlying calculations to account for these decimals, which should make the output more accurate.

### Additional Context

- Similar issues have been discussed on [GitHub](https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/issues/522) and [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73621705/uniswap-liquidity-calculation-issue-on-arbitrum-chain).
- This is particularly important for USDC pairs, where the discrepancy can be significant due to differing decimals.

## Detailed Description of Changes:

* Code Formatting and Readability:

The code has been formatted to follow a consistent style, with appropriate indentation and line breaks to enhance readability. Comments have been provided for each function, explaining its purpose and properties. The mostSignificantBit and leastSignificantBit functions are now more readable and easier to understand due to improved code organization. Error Messages in require Statements:

The require statements in both functions now include specific error messages to provide more informative feedback when the input value (x) is not greater than 0. The error messages make it clear that the value must be greater than 0 for the functions to produce valid results. Executive Summary of Changes:

The optimized version of the BitMath library focuses on improving code readability and providing more informative error messages while preserving the efficient bit manipulation capabilities. The key changes include code formatting and organization, adding descriptive comments, and enhancing the error messages in require statements.

## Advantages of the Changes:

* Readability and Maintainability: The optimized version's consistent code formatting and descriptive comments improve code readability, making it easier for developers to understand and maintain the library in the future.

* Clarity in Error Messages: The addition of specific error messages in the require statements provides clear feedback to users when they input a value that does not meet the required condition (greater than 0). This improves user experience and helps in debugging potential issues.

* Code Consistency: The improvements in code formatting and organization lead to a more consistent codebase, reducing the chances of errors due to inconsistencies in the implementation.

* Efficient Bit Manipulation: Despite the changes made, the core logic for finding the most significant bit and least significant bit remains unchanged, ensuring efficient bit manipulation capabilities are retained.

1.title: Update UniswapV3Factory.sol :  [OPTIMISED]
1.body:
## Executive Summary:
The optimized Uniswap V3 Factory contract is an implementation of the Uniswap V3 decentralized exchange protocol. It allows users to create and manage pools with different fee structures. The contract efficiently deploys pools and manages ownership and control over pool protocol fees. The optimizations include code reusability, improved readability, and reduced duplication, resulting in a more maintainable and efficient smart contract.

## Extended Description:
The optimized Uniswap V3 Factory contract is a crucial component of the Uniswap V3 decentralized exchange ecosystem. It is responsible for deploying Uniswap V3 pools and managing ownership and control over pool protocol fees. The contract adheres to the specification defined by the IUniswapV3Factory interface, ensuring compatibility with other components of the Uniswap V3 protocol.

## Key Optimizations:

* Code Reusability and Readability:
The optimized version of the contract eliminates code duplication by introducing an internal function, setFeeAmountTickSpacing, to handle the setting of fee amounts and their corresponding tick spacings. By using a separate function for this purpose, the code becomes more readable and modular, promoting reusability of the fee-setting logic.

* Efficiency and Maintainability:
The contract leverages internal functions for operations that should only be accessible within the contract scope. This follows best practices for code design and encapsulates implementation details, making the contract more maintainable and secure. The optimized version improves the efficiency of the contract by removing redundant code and promoting cleaner code organization.

* Pool Deployment and Ownership Management:
The contract retains its core functionality, which allows users to create new Uniswap V3 pools by calling the createPool function. It verifies the uniqueness of the token pair, ensures valid token addresses, and checks for appropriate fee and tick spacing configurations. Additionally, the contract allows the current owner to transfer ownership by calling the setOwner function, and only the contract owner can enable new fee amounts and tick spacings.

## Conclusion:
The optimized Uniswap V3 Factory contract remains a critical smart contract for managing and deploying Uniswap V3 pools in a decentralized manner. By implementing code reusability, readability, and encapsulation, the contract becomes more maintainable and efficient. Users can trust in the integrity and security of the contract, enabling seamless liquidity provision and trading on the Uniswap V3 decentralized exchange platform. The contract's adherence to best practices and the Uniswap V3 protocol specification ensures its compatibility and reliability within the broader ecosystem.

TickBitmap, SwapMath, Oracle: replace "if (A && B)" to save gas fees
2.body:
The solidity compiler generates more code for “if (A && B) {}” than for “if (A) {if (B) {} }”.
Our experiment shows that switching from “if (A && B) {}” to “if (A) {if (B) {} }” can save gas fee.

There are six such cases:
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/TickBitmap.sol#L49
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/SwapMath.sol#L87
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/SwapMath.sol#L91
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/Oracle.sol#L93
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/Oracle.sol#L134
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/Oracle.sol#L179

Replacing 
```
if (targetAtOrAfter && lte(time, target, atOrAfter.blockTimestamp)) break;
```
with
```
if (targetAtOrAfter) {
    if (lte(time, target, atOrAfter.blockTimestamp)) {
         break;
    }
}
```
can save gas fees and does not hurt readability.

2.title: change SLOAD to MLOAD to save gas
2.body: Reading a state variable costs more gas than reading a local variable. If a state variable is read multiple times, it saves gas to cache the variable as a local variable and then read the local variable.

2.title: Unary operator misused, fails to compile with solidity v8.18
2.body:
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/d8b1c635c275d2a9450bd6a78f3fa2484fef73eb/contracts/libraries/FullMath.sol#L64

```
TypeError: Unary operator - cannot be applied to type uint256
  --> @uniswap/v3-core/contracts/libraries/FullMath.sol:64:24:
   |
64 |         uint256 twos = -denominator & denominator;
```

This line can be safely replaced by the following which is compatible with the newer solidity compilers: 

```solidity
uint256 twos = denominator & (~denominator + 1);
```

2.title: On the relationship between the pool and the NFT position manager
2.body:
Hi! I am trying to understand deeper the relationship between the `UniswapV3Pool.sol` contract in this repo and the `NonfungiblePositionManager.sol` contract in the `v3-periphery` repo. As a summary, my question is: How does the pool contract know which position to burn if the message sender owns more than 1 position in a single tick range?

## Minting Liquidity
I mint liquidity via the NFT manager since it implements a `uniswapV3MintCallback`. The NFT contract calls the `addLiquidity` method with parameters
```
AddLiquidityParams({
      token0: params.token0,
      token1: params.token1,
      fee: params.fee,
      recipient: address(this),
      tickLower: params.tickLower,
      tickUpper: params.tickUpper,
      amount0Desired: params.amount0Desired,
      amount1Desired: params.amount1Desired,
      amount0Min: params.amount0Min,
      amount1Min: params.amount1Min
})
```
In particular, note how the recipient is defined as the NFT manager contract. This maps up to the `mint` on the pool contract:
```
function mint(
      address recipient,
      int24 tickLower,
      int24 tickUpper,
      uint128 amount,
      bytes calldata data
  ) external override lock returns (uint256 amount0, uint256 amount1)
```
which then goes on to modify a position of the NFT contract
```
_modifyPosition(
    ModifyPositionParams({
        owner: recipient,
        tickLower: tickLower,
        tickUpper: tickUpper,
        liquidityDelta: int256(amount).toInt128()
    })
);
```

## Burning Liquidity
I can burn liquidity directly on the pool contract without going through the NFT contract. I just need to supply the tick range and the amount of liquidity I'd like to burn:
```
function burn(
    int24 tickLower,
    int24 tickUpper,
    uint128 amount
) external override lock returns (uint256 amount0, uint256 amount1)
```
But how does the pool know which position to burn? I believe this comes in the modify position section of the code:
```
_modifyPosition(
    ModifyPositionParams({
        owner: msg.sender,
        tickLower: tickLower,
        tickUpper: tickUpper,
        liquidityDelta: -int256(amount).toInt128()
    })
);
```
so the pool burns liquidity of the position in the tick range owned by the owner of the message, so I'd need to send the transaction from the NFT contract address which is the owner of the liquidity minted in the first section. This is reinforced by the NFT contract which calls the following code in the `decreaseLiquidity` method
```
(amount0, amount1) = pool.burn(position.tickLower, position.tickUpper, params.liquidity);
```
This implies that the pool knows the NFT contract has sent the message so knows the NFT contract liquidity should be burned.

## Problem
However, the NFT position manager contract has loads of positions, since the majority of NFT positions are owned by the NFT manager contract. The position is obtained by the following line
```
position = positions.get(owner, tickLower, tickUpper);
```
But there will be multiple NFTs that have the same tick range, and so this method should have multiple valid responses of positions with the NFT contract owner with that tick range. So how does the pool contract know which particular position to remove liquidity from?

Even if the `liquidtyNext` variable is not used when the liquidityDelta is 0, below code assigns the value to the `liquidtyNext`. 
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/05c10bf6d547d6121622ac51c457f93775e1df09/contracts/libraries/Position.sol#L53-L56

https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/05c10bf6d547d6121622ac51c457f93775e1df09/contracts/libraries/Position.sol#L69

Therefore, there is no need to assign self.liquidty value to liquidityNext in line 55. Unnecessary mstore().

2.title: Etherscan contract interface does not check for authentication, Large number of admin functions callable by public, XSS vulnerability in etherscan.
2.body:
Please see this information as it APPLIES TO UNISWAP also:

#### Expected behaviour
- Many functions across all contracts are publicly callable that are clearly only intended for admins of the contract to use, it is as though there is no authentication happening in most contracts for some contract function calls whatsoever.
- The 'Write Contract' interface should prompt for authentication to make clicking the writable functions more difficult.
- The form processing done on input from text boxes on the smart contract interface screens of "Read Contract" / "Write Contract" should filter special characters when receiving input, at least for double quotes and their various representations in hex, decimal, unicode, html entities, escaped JavaScript, etc.  Code can currently be injected into function calls by escaping the double quotes character and at a minimum cause exceptions as a method of burning gas on purpose ( not all gas is reverted upon certain exceptions).

#### Actual behaviour
The public can manipulate some of the top contracts, potential for data corruption via XSS on etherscan, writeable panel of contract interface issues network requests on button clicks even if user is not logged in.  ( No error message or success message is displayed, but the request is sent and received and processed by the server when the button is pressed. )
Some contracts that I was able to look at on goerli had nearly every writable function callable anonymously by the public without doing a proper transaction or requiring coins to issue.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
View a contract on testnet like this one, go to "Write Contract" and enter zeros into each field, hit submit, and you have written to the contract without spending coins. - https://goerli.etherscan.io/address/0x8ae7063d03213d4d90103c16f048b3f64de2d4d0#code

I have been trying to submit and get attention to these problems for some time now, to both an almost comical and embarassing degree, and after being completely ignored and seeing as this is being obviously abused I decided it better to post here so that people are made aware of the situation sooner than later.  I had reported this to solidity but have not heard back anything from them and in my opinion it is too late to siliently roll out a fix.

2.title: Error in the Optimism Uniswap v3 contract ETH-WETH - lost 30 ETH
2.body:
**Sequence of events:**

**Rabby wallet** used for the transaction ([https://rabby.io/](https://deref-mail.com/mail/client/gnXUKv-ECYo/dereferrer/?redirectUrl=https%3A%2F%2Frabby.io%2F)) downloaded from chrome store. **Brave browser** (v 1.43.93) running in **Windows 10 Home 21H2**
1. Connected to [https://app.uniswap.org/#/swap](https://deref-mail.com/mail/client/BjOq9hWvNhs/dereferrer/?redirectUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fapp.uniswap.org%2F%23%2Fswap)

2. Selected the Optimism blockchain.

3. Swap 30 ETH to WETH in the UI. The button changed to "WRAP".

4. Transaction signed and sent, but instead wrapping, it transferred the 30 ETH to other wallet (0xc02aaa39b223fe8d0a0e5c4f27ead9083c756cc2), transaction hash 0x97be403fe3a77dc9a2083016d8bad2f69aae5a0574bda484726d0dcfb9704100

5. 30 ETH lost

Notified UNISWAP support team two months ago, still no response as to what has happened. Contacted the RABBY team, they are aware of the failure and have had other notifications, they are unable to provide further details. 

It seems that the contract that is referenced is the ETHEREUM Blockchain contract, rather than the Optimism WETH contract. Therefore, by interacting with the wrong contract, in the end, what it has done is to send the ETH to the address of the WETH contract on the ethereum blockchain.

This bug may be affecting networks other than ethereum.

2.title: Refund otherwise lost tokens (deposited using unsupported functions)
2.body:
Uniswap V3 pool only supports token deposit by approve/transferFrom. If a user deposits a token by transfer (by mistake), the token would be lost permanently in today's Uniswap V3 design. A more user-friendly design is to refund the otherwise lost tokens.

There are two designs to do so: 1) Redesign the pool smart contract for the next version of Uniswap (say V4). 2) The other direction is to build an off-chain service retrofittable to deployed Uniswap V3 pool contracts (i.e., without changing the smart contract).

2.title: Strange behaviour fees in range
2.body:
###  Preamble
According [uniswap whitepaper v3](https://uniswap.org/whitepaper-v3.pdf), we could calculate fees per share in the price range between two ticks with formulas 6.17 - 6.19:

$$\begin{equation}
  f_a(i)=\begin{cases}
    f_g - f_o(i), & i_c \geq i\\
    f_o(i), & i_c < i
  \end{cases}
\end{equation}
$$

$$\begin{equation}
  f_b(i)=\begin{cases}
    f_o(i), & i_c \geq i \\
    f_g - f_o(i), & i_c < i
  \end{cases}
\end{equation}
$$

$$f_r = f_g - f_b(i_l) - f_a(i_u)$$

$f_r$ - fees for given range
$f_g$ - fees earned in all pool (variable `feeGrowthGlobal0X128` / `feeGrowthGlobal1X128` in pool smart contract)
$f_b(i)$ - fees earned below tick $i$
$f_a(i)$ - fees earned above tick $I$

$i_l$ - lower tick for given range
$i_u$ - upper tick for given range
$f_o$ - `feeGrowthOutside0X128` / `feeGrowthOutside1X128` in tick state

Here is simplified version of [original code](https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/main/contracts/libraries/Tick.sol#L60) for calculation accumulated fees in range:
```solidity
function getFeeGrowthInside(
    mapping(int24 => Tick.Info) storage self,
    int24 tickLower,
    int24 tickUpper,
    int24 tickCurrent,
    uint256 feeGrowthGlobalX128,
) internal view returns (uint256 feeGrowthInsideX128) {
    Info storage lower = self[tickLower];
    Info storage upper = self[tickUpper];

    uint256 feeGrowthBelowX128;
    if (tickCurrent >= tickLower) {
        feeGrowthBelowX128 = lower.feeGrowthOutsideX128;
    } else {
        feeGrowthBelowX128 = feeGrowthGlobalX128 - lower.feeGrowthOutsideX128;
    }

    uint256 feeGrowthAboveX128;
    if (tickCurrent < tickUpper) {
        feeGrowthAboveX128 = upper.feeGrowthOutsideX128;
    } else {
        feeGrowthAboveX128 = feeGrowthGlobalX128 - upper.feeGrowthOutsideX128;
    }

    feeGrowthInsideX128 = feeGrowthGlobalX128 - feeGrowthBelowX128 - feeGrowthAboveX128;
}
```

###  Problem
Ok, lets try to calculate fees for [pool USDC/USDT - 0.01% on polygon](https://polygonscan.com/address/0xdac8a8e6dbf8c690ec6815e0ff03491b2770255d).

Block: [31995913](https://polygonscan.com/block/31995913)
Tick lower: -6
Tick upper: -2

Calculations for token0: 
<details>
<summary>Python implementation of fees calculation</summary>

It uses my wrapper for web3 - web3 premium, but nothing rocket science here is
```python
import datetime

from web3_premium.chains import polygon
from web3_premium.contract import Contract
from web3_premium.utils import get_block_by_datetime


BLOCK = int(
    get_block_by_datetime(polygon.explorer, datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 17, 16, 0))
)
usdt_usdc_01_pool = Contract("0xdac8a8e6dbf8c690ec6815e0ff03491b2770255d", polygon)


def tick_growth_outside(tick):
    # get feeGrowthOutside0X128 from tick info for given tick and block
    return usdt_usdc_01_pool.ticks(tick, block=BLOCK)[2]


def get_fee_growth_inside(tick_lower, tick_upper, tick_current, fee_growth_global):
    print(f"$i_l$ = {tick_lower}")
    print(f"$i_u$ = {tick_upper}")
    print(f"$i_c$ = {tick_upper}")
    print(f"$f_g$ = {fee_growth_global}")
    print(f"$f_o(i_l)$ = {tick_growth_outside(tick_lower)}")
    print(f"$f_o(i_u)$ = {tick_growth_outside(tick_upper)}")

    if tick_current >= tick_lower:
        fee_growth_below = tick_growth_outside(tick_lower)
        print("$i_c \geq i_l$")
        print("$f_b(i_l) = f_o(i_l)$")
    else:
        fee_growth_below = fee_growth_global - tick_growth_outside(tick_lower)
        print("$i_c < i_l$")
        print("$f_b(i_l) = f_g - f_o(i_l)$")
    print(f"$f_b(i_l)$ = ${fee_growth_below}")

    if tick_current < tick_upper:
        fee_growth_above = tick_growth_outside(tick_upper)
        print("$i_c < i_u$")
        print("$f_a(i_u) = f_o(i_u)$")
    else:
        fee_growth_above = fee_growth_global - tick_growth_outside(tick_upper)
        print("$i_c \geq i_u$")
        print("$f_a(i_u) = f_g - f_o(i_u)$")
    print(f"$f_a(i_u)$ = {fee_growth_above}")

    fee_growth_inside = fee_growth_global - fee_growth_below - fee_growth_above
    print(f"$f_r$ = {fee_growth_inside}")
    return fee_growth_inside


current_tick = usdt_usdc_01_pool.slot0(block=BLOCK)[1]
fee_growth_global = usdt_usdc_01_pool.feeGrowthGlobal0X128(block=BLOCK)
get_fee_growth_inside(-6, -2, current_tick, fee_growth_global)
```
</details>


$i_l$ = -6
$i_u$ = -2
$i_c$ = -2
$f_g$ = 52059057655713157425077904244139302
$f_o(i_l)$ = 48464060636512038136115728978196309
$f_o(i_u)$ = 2001227920504599228768954726169803

$i_c \geq i_l$
$f_b(i_l) = f_o(i_l)$
$f_b(i_l)$ = 48464060636512038136115728978196309

$i_c \geq i_u$
$f_a(i_u) = f_g - f_o(i_u)$
$f_a(i_u)$ = 50057829735208558196308949517969499

$f_r$ = -46462832716007438907346774252026506

So, the problem is that fees **could not be negative**.

### Question
So, I calculate fees with formula from whitepaper and get negative fees.

It is the bug or error in my calculations?

2.title: OracleLibrary incompatible with latest OpenZeppelin
2.body:
[OpenZepp](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/blob/master/contracts/access/Ownable.sol)

```
pragma solidity ^0.8.0;
```

incompatible with OracleLibrary which dictates `pragma solidity >=0.5.0 <0.8.0;`

Related: https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/issues/489
Related: https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/pull/525

"n this PR I update the pragmas of FullMath and TicketMath to be 0.8.0, as these do not compile with Solidity >=0.8.0. I also think this should be done out of safety, given FullMath relies on overflows and so, as I understand, will behave incorrectly if used with a solidity version >=0.8.0."

When will Uniswap support the latest Solidity version and become again compatible with the popular smart contract framework, Open Zeppelin?

2.title: Explicit conversions for Solidity 0.8.x compatibility
2.body:
This PR changes integer conversions from implicit to explicit ones in several places where implicit ones are no longer allowed in Solidity 0.8. The change does not change behavior, just makes the code (almost) compile on both 0.7.6 and 0.8.11.

I'm trying to compile Uniswap using the latest Solidity compiler so that it can be included in the suite of external tests. We use these tests to ensure that new releases do not break existing projects. The PR on its own is not enough to make the project compatible with 0.8.x but it reduces the number of changes needed and has no real downsides.

The PR omits [one place in `Oracle.sol` where a conversion is also needed](https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/9161f9ae4aaa109f7efdff84f1df8d4bc8bfd042/contracts/libraries/Oracle.sol#L277):
```diff
-((atOrAfter.tickCumulative - beforeOrAt.tickCumulative) / observationTimeDelta) *
+((atOrAfter.tickCumulative - beforeOrAt.tickCumulative) / int56(uint56(observationTimeDelta))) *
```
I'm omitting it because this one does have a downside: is not free. It results in the compiler inserting an extra `SIGNEXTEND` instruction that in the end does not get optimized out and increases the cost by 12 gas. I tried to compensate for it by optimizing the code around it but while it improves the cost in some tests, for some reason it makes others more expensive.

2.title: Constrain FullMath pragma to <0.8.0
2.body: In this PR I update the pragmas of FullMath and TicketMath to be `0.8.0`, as these do not compile with Solidity >=0.8.0. I also think this should be done out of safety, given FullMath relies on overflows and so, as I understand, will behave incorrectly if used with a solidity version >=0.8.0.

3.title: Add compability for solc 0.8
3.body:
Many of the current v3 core libraries do not work with solc 0.8 in their present state, bc of their dependency on FullMath, TickBitmap or TickMath which contain some code that gives compilation error on solc 0.8.

Though after the changes in this PR the `FullMath.spec.ts`, `TickBitmap.spec.ts` and `TickMath.spec.ts` tests pass. But the gas tests fail. Also it changes the UniswapV3Pool bytecode. Hence, the PR does not intend to be merged on main branch.

FWIW, it would be great if Uniswap can publish an official `@uniswap/v3-core-0.8-support` kind of package, so that projects can conveniently build on Uniswap V3 using solc 0.8, without copy-pasting files to their repo and modifying code (which could potentially violate licences).

3.body:
Hello,

  I'm working with https://github.com/Bella-DeFinTech/uniswap-v3-simulator/ to rebuild Pool state from chain Events to evaluate and fork the Pool and feed it different positions/swaps for trading.

  At the moment I am attempting to build the current state of Pool ETH/ENS [0x92560C178cE069CC014138eD3C2F5221Ba71f58a](https://etherscan.io/address/0x92560c178ce069cc014138ed3c2f5221ba71f58a)
  The problem is to calculate which AmountSpecified was (which is not in the Swap event) we need to pass both Amount0 and Amount1 in, and determine which gives us the correct AmountOutput.

  Now on this Pool I am using, passing the SwapEvent.SqrtPriceX96 does not give the same behavior to the Pool as passing an Empty SqrtPriceX96. This is because of the way the Fee is calculated depending on whether the ComputeSwap function has been passed the SqrtPriceLimitX96, or the top of the current Tick (SqrtPriceNextX96).

  _This means that counterintuitively, you get MORE tokens by not supplying a limit price, than by specifying one. Albeit by 1 LSB in this case, but I have seen instances when looking at pools of 5 or more._
  Above is incorrect, you SPEND more tokens, which DOES make sense. However the rounding issue does exist and can reach 5 or so units, and so we are having trouble rebuilding the whole state.

  Here is the test I have run for this, the offending Transaction is the first Swap event on the above pool: [0x4d8a042cae977aa124cda85419461093fb87b04814126e024a05dc4f8252e27a](https://etherscan.io/tx/0x4d8a042cae977aa124cda85419461093fb87b04814126e024a05dc4f8252e27a)

3.title: What is the significance of 3402992956809132418596140100660247210 and 291339464771989622907027621153398088495 in TickMath?
3.body:
I'm trying to understand Uniswap's logarithm implementation. What I've understood till now:

1. First find MSB of the number, which gives an approximate value of log2. This log2 value is in Q192.64 format
2. Further refine log2 using 14 assembly operations
3. Change of base rule: Change base to √1.0001 by multiplying with `2^64 / log2 (√1.0001) = 255738958999603826347141`. Obtained value is Q128.128

It seems that `log_sqrt10001` gives the fractional tick in U.128. From variable names, it looks like we want to find the largest whole number tick which gives `f(t) < √P`. We find tickLow and tickHi for this purpose, by adding/subtracting some value from the fractional tick. But won't arbitrary values (x, y) satisfying `x+y < 1` such as 0.4 and 0.4 work? What is the significance of these two numbers?

- `3402992956809132418596140100660247210 = 0.01 x 2^128`
- `291339464771989622907027621153398088495 = 0.856 x 2^128`

Since we find log2 fractional value till 14 bits, it leaves us an error margin of `2^-14 / log2(√1.0001) = 0.8461`. Each value should be a multiple of `0.8461`, so why not add/subtract this number to get adjacent ticks?

https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/c05a0e2c8c08c460fb4d05cfdda30b3ad8deeaac/contracts/libraries/TickMath.sol#L200
https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/c05a0e2c8c08c460fb4d05cfdda30b3ad8deeaac/contracts/libraries/TickMath.sol#L201

Follow up from https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/a/113912/59991 and https://liaoph.com/logarithm-in-solidity/

3.title: feat: OVM
3.body:
# Summary

The OVM is a sandboxed environment for the EVM which allows execution of smart contract code on L2, with the ability to dispute it on L1 via a fraud proof. Solidity code can be compiled directly to OVM code instead of EVM code by using ["optimistic solc"](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/solidity), a fork of the well-known solc. The OVM bytecode is ~30% larger than EVM bytecode, which may result in the bytecode being larger than the 24kb size limit for smart contracts.

This PR refactors the codebase to allow it to fit in the 24kb limit, and does a minimal diff to the test suite so that tests can pass when ran against an instance of [go-ethereum running the OVM](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/tree/develop/l2geth). I suspect the test suite changes around waiting for txs to be confirmed would've been required anyway if we wanted to test against geth or any full node impl.
 
# Explanation of code changes

* Introduces a new CI job for the OVM unit tests
* Modifies the hardhat config in the following ways:
    * Overrides the default signer and contracts to always `.wait()`. This is because tests are run against go-ethereum which does not insta-mine, hence receipts are not immediately available in tests.
    * Overrides the default waffle getWallets() method because it fails if the network name is not `hardhat`
    * Makes Waffle fixtures a no-op. This is because go-ethereum does not support snapshots
    * Makes the default ethers provider polling interval 100ms. This is because when blocks don't get instamined, Ethers by default [waits 4s while polling](https://github.com/ethers-io/ethers.js/blob/5f1f2c5e2cb52e15bf88e0ef54efb7b5adc34cca/packages/providers/src.ts/base-provider.ts#L512)
    * Add a new network called `optimism`
    * Increase the mocha timeout, given that there's no fixtures to speed tests up
    * Decreases the optimizer runs to keep bytecode size low
    * Adds a new plugin, `hardhat-ovm` which allows compiling to the OVM when the target network has the `ovm: true` flag set
* Adds a `scripts/run-optimism.sh` script which will clone the Optimism monorepo, build it, and bring up the network
* Replaces the minimal proxy which contains [banned opcodes](https://hackmd.io/elr0znYORiOMSTtfPJVAaA?view#Unsupported-Opcodes) with a normal delegateproxy contract
* Refactors libraries with `internal` functions to `public`, so that they get deployed as separate contracts and do not contribute to the bytecode of the "main" contract. Certain functions were also batched together to minimize the number of `delegatecall`s needed (e.g. `updateBoth`).

# Status

All tests pass _both_ in the EVM _and_ in the OVM! Due to the lack of snapshots and running against a real node, tests take much longer, ~90mins.

The linter fails due to perms, but I formatted everything in the last commit.

h/t to @mds1 and @elenadimitrova for the help :)

3.title: Remove recipient/to field and use msg.sender instead
3.body:
In short: what is the reason behind the `recipient` design instead of just `msg.sender`?

From v2, the `to` (`recipient`) field seems odd in the smart-contract context. It detaches the output token ownership from the input token ownership. I'm not sure what the reason behind this design, but it causes some troubles in developing 3rd party contract.

I'm developing a decentralized bank, where user deposit their tokens and some *delegates* will execute farming operations (`swap`, `addLiquidity`, `removeLiquidity`, etc.) on behalf of the bank. The key decentralization here is that no *delegate* can withdraw any token, they can only tell the bank contract to interact with trusted pool/routers. If the protocol/periphery contracts mint/swap to `msg.sender`, the ownership of each token is kept intact. With `recipient` field as current design, extra operation has to be caried out for ownership verification.

3.title: accumulate seconds per liquidity instead of liquidity
3.body:
This change allows us to compute the seconds per `max(1, liquidity)` in a tick range, which enables a liquidity mining contract to reward a position's liquidity by its share pro rata of all active liquidity over the given period, assuming a fixed token reward rate per second.

In addition, it enables time weighted harmonic mean liquidity to be computed, which is _potentially_ safer for use in liquidity weighted geomean prices since it is biased towards lower values. It is no longer possible to compute the time weighted arithmetic mean liquidity.

3.title: Improve the 'divRoundingUp' function in the 'UnsafeMath' Library
3.body:
In the [UnsafeMath Library](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/main/contracts/libraries/UnsafeMath.sol#L14), you can improve this:
```
z = (x / y) + (x % y > 0 ? 1 : 0);
```
Which consists of 1 div, 1 add, 1 mod, 1 jump, 4 loads and 1 store.

To this:
```
z = x > 0 ? (x - 1) / y + 1 : 0;
```
Which consists of 1 div, 1 add, 1 sub, 1 jump, 3 loads and 1 store.

Even if we ignore the improvement of 3 vs 4 loads (say, the compiler can opt it out), we still replace the 'mod' operation (5 gas) with a 'sub' operation (3 gas).

A minor diff in the behavior: `divRoundingUp(0, 0)` will return 0 instead of panicking (divide by zero).

If this is critical, then you can slightly modify the suggested expression into:
```
z = x > 0 ? (x - 1) / y + 1 : x / y;
```
Which for `x == 0` will yield the same number of loads (3), alongside 1 div, 1 jump and 1 store (still better than your current implementation, which costs the same for both sides of the 'greaterThan' condition).

3.title: Allow fetching the required liquidity from amount0/amount1
3.body:
When adding liquidity, a user has no idea what `liquidity` means, but they do know how much they want to deposit in amount0/amount1 and where.

We add a new library with `getLiquidityDeltaForAmountX` methods, as well as echidna tests for the invariant. We always use `roundUp=true` for the `getAmountXDelta` functions since the scenario we're interested in always involves a positive liquidity delta.

We implement this by inverting (assuming hi/lo = sqrtPrice at upper/lower tick):
* `getAmount0Delta` which used to calculate `a0 = liquidity * (hi - lo) / (hi * lo)` to `liquidity0 = a0 * (hi * lo) / (hi - lo)`
* `getAmount1Delta` which used to calculate `a1 = liquidity * (hi - lo)` to `liquidity1 = a1 * (hi * lo) / (hi - lo)`.

We get the `liquidity = min(liquidity0, liquidity1)`.

# Notes / Questions
* I've added commit https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/pull/423/commits/74de259ded1b57775e51e458f8404c1aff399796 to show how this would get consumed but reverted it since it'd put the factory over the bytecode limit. We prob can just use this in the router to calculate things natively after fetching `slot0` for the pair we're LPing to.
* Highly levered positions have some minimal precision loss which is accounted for in the tests 
* How are we going to refactor this out to the Router? Is it OK to pull the `TickMath.getSqrtPriceAt` and `FullMath` lib functionalities and copy-paste it there?

3.title: feat: add router v3 interface
3.body:
An initial attempt, this is pretty close to the V2 Router. 3 Main changes
* Given how the Uniswap state transition is hard to write as a pure function due to the ticks mapping (mappings cannot be passed as public function args, only in internal Libraries), the `getAmount` functions use a `pair` address which they'll call to get any tick-related state they need.
* `path` is no longer an `address[]` but a `bytes32[]`. That will allow us to have the address of the token being swapped in the lower 20 bytes, and have the fee category in the upper 12 bytes.
* Instead of using min/max amounts when swapping, we use `sqrtPriceLimitX96`.


Questions:
* Currently, if `amountADesired` is set to 0, then you do "single sided" liquidity adding, by swapping then minting. Should this be done in a separate function?
* Should we add `sqrtPriceLimitX96` instead of `amountAMin` and `amountBMin`in addLiquidity`?
* Is exposing the state transition function as a `view` function an option or are we frozen? That would greatly simplify the implementations of `getAmountOut`
* It is still a bit unclear how we'll do multihop `exactIn` because we need to run the state transition function in reverse (and that may require non trivial math changes, but I haven't checked yet).
* Kinda feels like the `address; address; uint256` combo is a few too-many function args (stack too deep etc.), should we just pack them in a struct and use abi encoder v2?

specifically it should never allow any position to withdraw more fees than it is owed, assuming a total supply `< type(uint128).max` for both `token0` and `token1`

it is acceptable for tokens owed / fees owed to overflow back to 0 (users or protocol lose fees) if any position accumulates more than `type(uint128).max` in tokens owed from burn or fee growth, because of the assumption that the total supplies of both token0 and token1 do not exceed type(uint128).max

3.title: Penalize intrablock
3.body:
this PR introduces new behavior when burning liquidity. specifically, if a position burns liquidity in the same block in which liquidity was minted to it, it forgoes any fees earned between the mint + burn, which accrue to the protocol. this is intended to disincentivize fee siphoning sandwich attacks within a single block.

this can be (minimally) griefed as follows: every time a griefer sees your burn in the mempool, they can mint 1 wei to your position, forcing you to forgo fees earned since that mint. in the worst case, this simply acts as if you withdrew liquidity in that block before any fees were generated.

note: sandwichers can still add liquidity, earn fees on it, and remove 1 block later, but this pr forces them to keep their liquidity in for at least a block if they want the fees.

3.title: Full intra block sandwich penalty
3.body:
this pr prevents fees from being earned on liquidity added (or removed) within the same block as the fees being earned.

this is intended to prevent sandwich fee siphoning attacks, which are now disincentivized

note that without this pr, the sandwich attack can still be profitable in a fee-on-principal world (even if the fee is equal to the swap fee), as miners can add liquidity that earns fees in both directions against different swaps before removing

for "honest"  LPs, this has the small downside of being griefable in the following way: a griefer can force fees earned on liquidity after it's added, within the same block, to go to the protocol. similarly, they can force fees earned before a burn, within the same block, to go to the protocol. while somewhat annoying, this is basically fine; if we assume every position is griefed, it's simply as if liquidity can only be added after all fees are earned in a block, and removed before.

edit 1: a slightly more annoying grief is that if you're willing to send 2 txs in a block (the first minting 1 wei, the second just poking), you can grief any position out of any fees earned in a given block (fees earned between the 1 wei mint and the poke, that is...). ~mitigating this would require something like the minimum mint % increase in #391~

edit 2: addressed edit 1 by requiring that mints increase position liquidity by >= 1%. this prevents non-interested parties from forcing a position to forgo fees in a block as described above (at least for fees up to 1% of the position value)

3.title: linear fee penalty

labels.name: user experience
labels.description: improves experience of interacting with contracts

3.body:
this pr introduces a _fee penalty_. every time a positions is `mint`ed to, the current time is recorded. every time that position's fees are calculated, if the last time the position was `mint`ed to was < 1 minute ago (hard-coded param for the time being), fees accrued are discounted linearly. so, for 0 seconds (i.e. the position was minted in this block), all fees are foregone and given to the protocol; for 30 seconds, half.

note that this does introduce a griefing vector where you can force a position to forgo fees accrued within the last minute by paying the gas for it, but once the threshold has passed you're guaranteed not to be penalized on already earned fees. ~if we like this general approach it's probably worth thinking a bit more about this attack and possible further mitigations. for example, we could require that minting an additional amount to a position must be at least some % of the current liquidity, etc.~

we also don't have to decay the penalty if we're worried about e.g. mining 2 blocks in a row

update: to address the griefing vector, i added an implementation requiring a 1% increase in liquidity per `mint`

4.title: Suggestion: Pass on more information to recipient on `uniswapV3FlashCallback`
4.body:
The `flash` [callback](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/ce452dd07ead8f1dd3274f669930240e20a5e2d6/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L637) is unnecesarily terse in the parameters it uses. Even if the initiator and the recipient of the flash loan are the same contract, the recipient usually needs to know the tokens and amounts lent.

This could be done by the users themselves by encoding the tokens and amounts in `data`, and then decoding them on the callback. It could also be done (more expensively) by the receiver by querying the lender on the tokens it works with, and by tracking their own balances for those.

However, it would be a better experience to let them know of these parameters in the callback.

4.title: Suggestion: Arbitrary recipients on `UniswapV3Pair`
4.body:
Consider allowing flash loans to arbitrary recipients [here](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/ce452dd07ead8f1dd3274f669930240e20a5e2d6/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L637).

Callbacks to `msg.sender` is more difficult to get wrong on the user side, but prevent building router functionality that would be useful for Uniswap.

A router could be built where the user specifies the token/s to borrow, with the router determining the most appropriate pair. For that a `recipient` would need to be specified in `flash`, and a `sender` in `uniswapV3Callback`.

If that is done, `uniswapV3FlashCallback` should be required to return a sentinel value such as `keccak256(IUniswapV3FlashCallback.uniswapV3FlashCallback` to avoid an attack where the recipient is drained of funds through fees on unsolicited loans.

Even if there is no intention for UniswapV3 to be fully compliant with [ERC3156](https://github.com/albertocuestacanada/ERC3156), its security considerations and reference implementation are a good source of examples for safe use of flash loans from the user side.

labels.name: user experience
labels.description: improves experience of interacting with contracts

4.body:
fixes https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/issues/331

reasons to merge this are:
- `minTick`/`maxTick` do not get special treatment, clients do not care about them on per pair basis, they just care about which ticks they can use and can't
- min tick and max tick are easily computed off chain from tick spacing, which can be hard coded per fee level in the client
- this pr also makes it possible to trade all the way up to the min/max price
- the sqrt price limit parameter is no longer optional and must always be valid (in the direction of the trade), which is better ux since there are no special values/invalid prices that can be passed to it (e.g. `type(uint160).max` or `0`)

5.title: create a minimal-`transfer` multihop-capable router

labels.name: periphery
labels.description: work that is external to the core contracts

5.body:
now that callback pay has been merged (#83), we can explore what an MVP multi-hop router would look like.

specifically, let's start with a version of `TestUniswapV3Callee` that allows _exact output_ swaps from A -> B -> C, where the steps look like:

1) initiate an exact output swap on the BxC pair, resulting in a transfer of C from BxC to user
2) within the (outer) swap callback, initiate an exact swap on AxB, resulting in a transfer of B to BxC
3) in the inner swap callback, resolve by triggering a transfer of A from user to AxB (via transferFrom)

5.title: remove liquidity accumulator and pack with sqrt price

5.body:
callback pay refers to the pattern of a) the pair checking its balance, b) the pair calling a function on an address that would have to send tokens to the pair, and then c) the pair checking its balance to make sure it received enough tokens. if we're going to introduce callback pay anywhere, it _probably_ makes sense to introduce it everywhere

this is in opposition to callback notify, which uses the callback simply to give an execution frame to flash swappers. if we use callback notify, it should only be used in `swap`, and only for flash swaps (indicated by `data.length > 0`)

a consideration in both cases is that all transferFrom calls should be sandwiched by balance checks enforcing correctness. we get this for free in callback pay, but it has to be enforced in callback notify


both variants have downstream implications for routers/integrations, which should also be explored as part of this decision

there's a griefing vector right now where it is possible to flash mint a bunch of liquidity that votes for the highest fee, force swappers to pay it, then remove liquidity. this is an accentuation of the "attack" described in the v2 audit: https://uniswap.org/audit.html#org8a14920

we could ameliorate this by just using the feeFloor as the fee directly and not as a fee floor, reverting back to the economics of the "attack" in v2

6.body:
https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/6b093302690ddee81140680d1b8013acaa010558/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L378-L379

if necessary, we may consider setting feeLast in initialize to prevent the following attack, where within one block the following sequence of events happens:
- user A initializes a pair
- user A sets position on the pair using high fee vote X
then...
- user B flash loans enough assets to change the pair fee vote
- user B swaps against the pair using the user A's liquidity and a lower fee
- user B removes liquidity

the effect is user B can use user A's liquidity to swap at a lower fee than user A preferred

6.title: geometric mean twap
6.body:
we need to implement an accumulator of the `log(price)` to allow external contracts to compute geometric TWAP

we have at least two options here for getting `log(price)`:
- compute the `log(price)`
- - changes with every swap, thus must be updated on the first swap of every block
- - can only really be packed with price
- - price right now is 128x128 which takes a full word, so would need to be changed
- use the tick
- - may not change with every swap
- - less precision
- - 16 bits * 64 bits timestamp that can be packed with `tickCurrent` and `blockTimestampLast`

also relevant is whether 1% is the final tick size we will use in v3

6.title: explore `sqrt` correctness/efficiency
6.body:
our desired `sqrt` implementation should satisfy: `computed_result = floor(true_result)`

the current implementation of `sqrt`:

- may not have this property because of a possible issue with the proof (TBD - https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-lib/issues/25)
- there is another candidate implementation which seems to be much cheaper (https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-lib/pull/23), but may not have our desired property
- it's _possible_ that we might want 512-bit support, to ameliorate rounding errors. something like `mulRoot` (analogous to [`mulDiv`](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-lib/blob/master/contracts/libraries/FullMath.sol#L35)) may be worth exploring (see e.g. [where `sqrt` is used in the current code](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/master/contracts/libraries/PriceMath.sol#L46))

6.body:
This could be used e.g. for delegating tokens held by the pair to other contracts, or collecting rewards owed to holders of `token0`/`token1`

However there are risks
- could be used to call approve on the `token0`/`token1` contract
- could be used to call `increaseAllowance`/`decreaseAllowance` on `token0`/`token1` contract
- could be used to call another contract that can spend `token0`/`token1` without approvals
  - this is protected by balance invariant

The risks are offset by:
- calls would have to come from `UniswapV3Factory#owner` which is probably not a malicious actor

Some other ways to mitigate the risk:
- blocklist certain call signatures (e.g. approve, increaseAllowance, decreaseAllowance)
  - this is preferred since the pair never needs to approve another address--it can always just transfer to another contract
  - the blocklist would be append-only by `owner` so new methods of approving could also be blacklisted
- alternately decode `approve`/`increaseAllowance`/`decreaseAllowance` calls and check that the allowance for any specified addresses is always 0

6.title: decide whether `setPosition` should result in an increase or decrease in `g`
6.body:
as a reminder: `g := sqrt(reserve0 * reserve1) / virtualSupply`

conceptually, _calls to `setPosition` should not change `g`_. to see why, consider the case where `setPosition` is being called to collect earned fees (i.e. `liquidityDelta = 0`). these fees were generated by swappers who _increased `g` as a function of paying the LP fee in addition to the `x * y = k` effect_. withdrawing the fees _should not change `g`_. so, because reserves are being removed, `virtualSupply` must also decrease. however, in many cases it may not be possible to add/remove exactly the right amount of `virtualSupply`, necessarily changing `g`. so, we have to decide if it's better to round up or down, essentially

6.title: decide on `TOKEN_MIN` (and `{MIN,MAX}_TICK`)
6.body:
the idea behind `TOKEN_MIN` is that if we enforce a minimum amount of tokens on both sides of a pair, we can guarantee that it's always possible to trade into the very next tick up or down (even if that trade involves sending 1 wei of input and receiving 0 output)

while 100 is the "right" minimum (see following example)...

initial state
`reserve0`: 100
`reserve1`: 100
`price`: 1
`tick`: 0

minimum trade of 0 for 1
`reserve0`: 101
`reserve1`: 100
`price`: .9̅9̅0̅0̅
`tick`: -1

minimum trade of 1 for 0
`reserve0`: 100
`reserve1`: 101
`price`: 1.01
`tick`: 1

...in practice, because our tick -> price math is not exact, and involves rounding, its almost certain that there are cases where this method would lead to us "skipping" a tick. so, for now, `TOKEN_MIN` is 101. however, it's important to validate that this is enough to guarantee our desired property always holds. also, where this condition is enforced in several different places right now, it's possible these could be consolidated. once we settle on a safe `TOKEN_MIN`, we should restrict `{MIN,MAX}_TICK` accordingly, so that we're not "wasting" tick space corresponding to prices that can never be reached. finally, we should also make sure we're efficiently enforcing the min/max tick condition when we settle on a final value

6.title: more robust price math testing + add incomplete pair echidna test
adding/removing reserves at tick crossings in `_swap` can cause the price to move in the wrong direction
6.body:
specifically, `_swap` is responsible for adding/removing reserves as ticks are crossed. it can be the case that it is impossible to add or remove reserves at the exact ratio of the current price, meaning that the price (`reserve1Virtual/reserve0Virtual`) changes. the 4 possible cases are shown by [`assert` and `require` statements in the code](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/master/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L675). so:

1) we would like validation that the price moving in the _correct_ direction (past the tick), is an acceptable outcome
2) if so, ideally we would be able to formally prove that these asserts can never be reached, and remove them from the deployed bytecode
3) if the price ever moves in the wrong direction, this poses a problem. right now, this case is prevented by `require` statements statements in the code, though of course this is less than ideal

6.title: calling `setPosition` can cause the price to move outside of the current tick
6.body:
specifically, `setPosition` can involve up to 3 calls to `updateReservesAndVirtualSupply`, which is responsible for updating reserves. it can be the case that it is impossible to add or remove reserves at the exact ratio of the current price, meaning that the price (`reserve1Virtual/reserve0Virtual`) changes. If liquidity is being added, the price can increase, if liquidity is being removed, the price can decrease. this is shown by [`assert` statements in the code](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/master/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L360). so:

1) ideally, we would be able to formally prove that these asserts can never be reached, and remove them from the deployed bytecode

2) if the price ever moves outside of the current tick, this poses a problem, as we only want to run the tick transition logic for swaps. right now, this case is prevented by [`require` statements in the code](https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/master/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L502), though of course this is less than ideal

7.title: fix comment
fix fee at the beginning of the block
7.body:
in uniswap v2, oracle price accumulators were modified _before_ the first action of every block that could potentially change the price. this prevented bad price manipulation behavior via flash loans, force-sending assets to the contract, etc.

similarly, in uniswap v3, we have to modify the current fee vote _before_ the first action of every block that could potentially change it. this will prevent someone from flash loaning a bunch of liquidity, voting for the lowest fee, and obviating the vote of existing LPs.

the median fee vote can only change on calls to `setPosition` and tick crossings, so we have to figure out an elegant way to update the global fee _before_ the first `setPosition`/tick crossing of every block. it's possible we can piggy-back on the `timeElapsed` check we use for the oracle (https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/05ee4361f34ec5e544f0843943844d8dbab1fe9a/contracts/UniswapV3Pair.sol#L214), or there may be more efficient ways to do this.

7.title: Broken invariant when removing liquidity
perf: unroll the fee vote calculation
7.body:
I think that unrolling the loop results in more efficient bytecode here? No benchmarks yet to test, hence opening as a draft. This has 3 conditionals and 5 MSTOREs vs having the loop, 2 conditionals and a redundant MSTORE in the final iteration of the while loop on the accumulator.

Also, since there is an even number of virtual supplies, we compute the median is calculated by taking mean of the two middlemost numbers - which is not what we're doing here. I guess it's fine to leave the computation as is, but let's not call it the median, to avoid confusion?

7.title: Decision on limit orders at ticks vs. one way leverage
Move counterfactual logic for reading price0Cumulative and price1Cumulative to pair

labels.name: user experience
labels.description: improves experience of interacting with contracts

7.body:
When reading price*CumulativeLast variables, all oracle consumers _actually_ want the cumulative price as of the current block, not the last liquidity event (e.g. mint/burn/swap)

We provided a library in uniswap v2 periphery for this
https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v2-periphery/blob/master/contracts/libraries/UniswapV2OracleLibrary.sol#L16

However, we should just add the `view` method directly to the pair `getCumulativePrices() returns (price0Cumulative, price1Cumulative)` that returns the cumulative prices as of the current block, even if there was no liquidity event.

Also potentially consider marking the `Last` suffixed variables private, if we want to force others to use this other method.

7.title: Scale up the initial liquidity tokens for usability
7.body:
Suggest scaling up initial liquidity tokens by `10^(18 - (min(token0Decimals, token1Decimals))` if `token0Decimals < 18` or `token1Decimals < 18` 

This will help us with a lot of wallet UX bugs and even uniswap frontend bugs (4 significant figures can be a very large string in our UI), in addition to computing useful token symbols and names
